sentences.text: The 2021 Chilean general election|2021 presidential election saw left-wing candidate Gabriel Boric, a former student protest leader during the 2011–2013 Chilean student protests|2011–2013 student protests, defeat conservative rival José Antonio Kast in a runoff. Boric's victory was attributed to widespread youth mobilization, dissatisfaction with the center-right administration of Sebastián Piñera, and economic strains following the COVID-19 pandemic in Chile|COVID-19 pandemic. His platform emphasized social equity, feminist reforms, and a "dignified life" for marginalized groups, pledging to dismantle Chile's "patriarchal inheritance."

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Bonnefoy |first=Pascale |last2=Londoño |first2=Ernesto |date=19 December 2021 |title=Gabriel Boric, a Former Student Activist, Is Elected Chile’s Youngest President |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/19/world/americas/chile-president-election.html |access-date=17 July 2023 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last= |date=20 December 2021 |title=Leftist millennial vows to remake Chile after historic win |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/20/boric-leftist-millennial-vows-to-remake-chile-after-historic-win.html |access-date=17 July 2023 |website=CNBC |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Cambero |first=Fabian |last2=Esposito |first2=Anthony |last3=Miranda |first3=Natalia A. Ramos |date=20 December 2021 |title=Chile's Boric pledges an orderly economy, swift naming of Cabinet |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/chiles-left-cheers-boric-win-ripples-through-latin-america-2021-12-20/ |access-date=17 July 2023 |work=Reuters |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Upon taking office in March 2022,  Boric appointed Chile's first gender-balanced cabinet, with women holding 14 of the 24 ministerial positions. His administration pursued several key policy initiatives, including pension reforms aimed at replacing the privatized system established under Augusto Pinochet and a proposal to nationalize the lithium mining industry. Boric also sought to implement stricter gun control measures and expand LGBTQ rights in Chile|LGBT rights, including protections for gender identity. Additionally, his government introduced progressive tax reforms focused on wealth redistribution and worked to secure approval for a new Constitution.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Bartlett |first=John |date=21 January 2022 |title=Chile’s president-elect names progressive, majority-women cabinet |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/21/chile-gabriel-boric-cabinet-majority-women |access-date=17 July 2023 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

sentences.text: By mid-2023, Boric's approval ratings had plummeted to 28%, with 66% disapproving of his administration, according to polls. Analysts cited economic stagnation, legislative gridlock, and public safety concerns as primary factors. The right-wing Republican Party (Chile)|Republican Party, led by Kast, capitalized on this discontent, securing a dominant victory in the 2023 Chilean Constitutional Council election|May 2023 Constitutional Council elections. Kast declared the results a mandate for "a major change in government," positioning himself as a frontrunner for 2025. Meanwhile, Evelyn Matthei of the Independent Democratic Union (UDI) has also gained traction in opinion polls.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=27 June 2023 |title=Chile’s President Boric Takes Another Blow to Popularity as Graft Accusations Hit Key Allies |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-27/chile-s-boric-sees-approval-fall-after-graft-accusations-against-coalition-party |access-date=17 July 2023 |work=Bloomberg.com |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text:
* Chamber of Deputies: The 155 members are elected from 28 multi-member constituencies (3–8 seats each) using open-list proportional representation with the d'Hondt method.
* Senate: The 50 senators serve staggered eight-year terms. Half the chamber (25 seats) is renewed each general election, elected from 16 regional constituencies (2–5 seats each) under similar proportional rules.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Political structure |url=http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=322002015&Country=Chile&topic=Summary&subtopic=Poli_5 |access-date=17 July 2023 |website=country.eiu.com}}</ref>

sentences.text: * Vlado Mirosevic (Liberal Party of Chile (2013)|Liberal Party), deputy for the 1st district in the Arica y Parinacota Region|Arica and Parinacota Region, was initially set to participate in the center-left primaries. He had been proclaimed as the party’s presidential candidate on 12 October 2024. However, since the party was not constituted at the national level, it needed to collect 35,361 signatures to validate his candidacy. As of 31 March, the party had only 9,851 registered members—far from the required number before the 29 April deadline. Mirosevic dropped out of the race on 16 April 2025 and announced his support for Carolina Tohá.<ref name=":1" />
